ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: There was no feedback on required response papers. For those interested in theory, this class was invaluable. In terms of practical application...that could be expanded on. I'm not sure the course was designed to have a common thread beyond agrarian societies. Maybe an intro or wrap up with common themes.
This is an excellent inter-disciplinary course. I recommend this course to anyone who has an open mind and is ready to challenge their preconceived notions.

3. There is SO MUCH reading for this course! I imagine that the instructors must know that it's really not feasible to do200+ pages of reading a week--not when you're taking other classes that also require a lot of time.
This course was a blessing. I am grateful to learn under professors such as James Scott. It was one of the best experiences of my fall semester.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Engaging discussions, expert professors, an interesting mix of students.
class discussion

The rotation of the professors fit well with the inter-disciplinary nature of the course. The lectures were interesting because they were not strictly confined to the subject matter of the book(s). The best aspect of the course is the discussion group - since it is a small group of students from different stages of study (undergraduate&graduate) and fields of study (history, anthropology, environmental studies). This is the most diverse set of students I have shared a class with here at Yale.
The best aspect of the course was the interdisciplinary approach to the material given by having three professors. The readings were always very engaging.
The subject matter is really interesting, and each of the professors is clearly brilliant and really interesting.

This is one of the best courses I have taken in the school. The course was interdisciplinary, focusing on current and very high standard analytical skill.The best aspect of the this course was the group discussion with students, where by students in turn lead discussion sessions on the reading materials. The discussions were high standard and relevant.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think the reading requirement should not exceed one book a week. Having two a week sometimes was too much.Further, for a paper worth 50% of our grade, it'd be nice to have a draft option in order to get some feedback.
continuity between classes and the "narrative thread" of the course. Maybe consider a Ta or TF
N/A - this class is perfect.
It seemed like a lot of the discussions were centered around theoretical discussion. I would have liked to talk about a more practical application of the material.

I think this class would be greatly benefitted by a TA. It was pretty easy to feel that the professors didn't really care too much about the students--or at least that they were not very communicative. It was hard to gauge what was expected of us, and we never got any feedback on our assignments.

All in all I found this course to be one of the best courses I have taken. The history part of the course entirely focused on China, which I thought could be improved by adding perspectives from other countries.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: It was very effective; I feel like I got to discuss the material with all three professors.
The two could be integrated a little better....talking about classroom themes in discussion or about book themes in lecture.
Yes, no room for improvement.
Sometimes there was disconnect between lecture and discussions. Lecture material was seldom brought up in discussion.

The discussion was often more interesting to me than the lecture, because it was more relevant to the reading, and more helpful for understanding conceptual material. Sometimes the lecture seemed only tangentially related to the readings.

The discussion and the lectures were consistent and complimentary. It was quite remarkable how the professors pulled this off to make it look natural.The course lectures provided a frame of thought while the discussion sessions offered cases to reflect up on using the frames.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am studying sustainable land use in developing countries.
I am studying a very specific agrarian society, and so it was helpful to learn about a great multitude of such societies.

I have a background in rural development and work with agrarian societies for some time. This course directly deals with agrarian societies; politics, history, development. This course spoke to me directly more than any other course did.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interest and its great reputation.
I am studying sustainable land use in developing countries.
To get an interdisciplinary introduction to agrarian studies.
To learn specifically where the agrarian society I'm studying fits into a broad spectrum of such societies.

I took this course for various reasons; among which.1. It deals with agrarian societies, a topic am directly involved in2. It is interdisciplinary and brought a students from different backgrounds; political science, environment, history, etc. The discussion sessions helped me gain new perspectives on issues.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes.

This class exceeded my expectations. This is the most challenging and intellectually engaging course I have taken while at Yale. The professors are leaders in their respective fields and still take the time to get to know the students and engage with them in the discussion sections. This very hands on approach allowed me to learn more from the professors and the other students.
Yes
Yes, on the whole.
Absolutely. It was the best experience. This is a course I would not mind taking over and over again.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to be part of the discussion sessions of this course as that is where most of the new insights and views are reflected up on.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Don't worry about the weekly presentations; just do the reading, think about it, and enjoy the discussion.
make an effort to get to know the people in your discussion group.

This is the best course I have taken at Yale. This course covers development, environmental, human rights, animal rights, indigenous peoples rights, agriculture and trade issues. It is intellectually engaging and challenging. If you are ready to read and open to discussing your thoughts and listening to differing points of view then you should take this course. You will not regret it.
Make sure to keep up on the reading and prepare a few things to say in discussion. It seems overwhelming but it's worth it.

i audited this class and did my best to do all the readings. i wish i had done a better job of doing them though. if you audit this class, do yourself a favor and keep up with the readings. they are awesome, and they make the lectures much richer experiences.
Overall, it's really interesting--just know that the reading load is immense (though you can usually get a away with not doing all of it), and professors can seem a bit distant.

The readings for this course tend to get intensive. As long as you're ready for that, it is the best course. Th fact that it was interdisciplinary, gave me perspectives I would not have gained if I was taking only environmental courses.
